That's a great idea! Your friends who participated in the Cycle for a Cause bike ride with you are likely already supportive of your charitable efforts, and they might be enthusiastic about helping you with your Run for the Cure fundraising campaign.

Here are some tips on how to ask them for their support:

**Leverage your shared experience**: Start by reminding them of the fun you had together during the Cycle for a Cause bike ride and how it brought you closer together. This shared experience can help create a sense of camaraderie and make them more likely to support your new endeavor.

**Emphasize the cause**: Explain why you're participating in the Run for the Cure event and why breast cancer research is important to you. Share your personal connection to the cause, if you have one, and highlight the impact that their support can make.

**Make it easy to help**: Provide a clear call-to-action, such as "Can you donate $10 to my fundraising campaign?" or "Would you be willing to share my fundraising page on social media?" Make it easy for them to take action and show their support.

**Show appreciation**: Express your gratitude for their potential support and acknowledge that you value their friendship. Let them know that their contribution, no matter how big or small, will make a difference.

**Example Message**:

"Hey friends! 👋 I hope you're all still basking in the glow of our awesome Cycle for a Cause bike ride on April 1st 🚴‍♀️. I'm excited to share with you that I'm now participating in the Run for the Cure event on May 15th to raise money for breast cancer research. 💪 As you know, I'm passionate about giving back to the community, and I'd love your support in this new endeavor. Would you be willing to donate $10 to my fundraising campaign or share my fundraising page on social media? Every bit counts, and I'd be forever grateful for your help! ❤️ Let me know if you're able to support me in any way. Thanks in advance for considering it!"

**Tips for Asking Friends for Support**:

* Be genuine and sincere in your ask. Your friends can tell if you're not being authentic.
* Keep your message concise and easy to read. Avoid lengthy paragraphs or complicated requests.
* Use a friendly and approachable tone. You're asking friends for support, not strangers.
* Be prepared for some friends to say no or not respond. Don't take it personally, and focus on those who are willing to help.

By asking your friends for support, you're not only raising money for a great cause but also strengthening your friendships and creating a sense of community. Good luck, and I hope you get the support you need!
